awd_titl_txt: Excellence in Research - Collaborative Research: Fate and transport of neonicotinoid insecticides in the environment
awd_abstract_narration:
Neonicotinoids were first used commercially starting in the 1990's. Since that time they have become the most widely used insecticides in the world. This widespread use has led to concerns regarding the potential for neonicotinoids to impact human and ecological health. Currently there are gaps in our understanding of neonicotinoid reactivity in the environment that hinder our ability to assess these impacts. This project will help address these gaps through a comprehensive study of the environmental fate and transport of neonicotinoids. The specific objectives are to understand how seven important neonicotinoid insecticides move, accumulate, and/or degrade in agricultural soils, surface water, and groundwater. Results will be used to develop and validate models to predict the long-term impacts of these compounds in the environment. The research will be carried out by a collaboration of researchers and students at Jackson State University and Tennessee State University, broadening participation and the diversity of the environmental engineering workforce.

Neonicotinoids have become the world's most widely used insecticides since they were first commercially used in the early 1990s. Such widespread use has led to concerns regarding the potential for neonicotinoids to impact human and ecological health.  This project will use a systematic and comprehensive approach to study the environmental fate and transport of the most widely used neonicotinoids in agricultural soils. To achieve this goal, the team will 1) examine the sorption and degradation of seven globally important neonicotinoids including imidacloprid, thiamethoxam, clothianidin, dinotefuran, acetamiprid, thiacloprid, and nitenpyram in three typical agricultural soils using laboratory batch tests; 2) investigate the transport and dissipation/accumulation of these neonicotinoids in soil environments in laboratory column tests, greenhouse simulation tests, and controlled field tests with multiple plant growing cycles; 3) investigate the dissipation/accumulation of neonicotinoids in surface water and groundwater at laboratory and pilot scale; and 4) study the long-term environmental impacts of neonicotinoids using fate and transport models verified with experimental data. The scaled-up greenhouse and field test data will advance understanding of the behavior of neonicotinoids in the environment at a level of breadth and depth necessary to verify the fate and transport simulation model. This model will allow the prediction of the long-term environmental impacts of the use of neonicotinoids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The environmental fate and transport of the seven neonicotinoids (imidacloprid, thiamethoxam, clothianidin, dinotefuran, acetamiprid, thiacloprid, and nitenpyram), a new generation of insecticides that are available on the market, were investigated through laboratory, greenhouse, and field tests. The main goal of the project was to understand the long-term environmental impacts of these insecticides through experiments and modeling with fate and transport models verified with experimental data.

Through laboratory tests on the adsorption and desorption characteristics of the neonicotinoids in typical agricultural soils in the southern United States, the degradation patterns and rates in soils and in waters, and the degradation products were discovered. The adsorption distribution coefficients in soils were found to be between 0.96 and 4.2 L/kg for the seven neonicotinoids in typical soil samples taken from Mississippi, Arkansas and Tennessee.

The degradation-in-soil test revealed that all these seven neonicotinoids degrade according to first-order kinetics and the half-lives ranging from 33 to 305 d, depending on the types of the neonicotinoids and soils. The Groundwater Ubiquity Score (GUS) derived from the experimental data indicate that six of the seven neonicotinoids (except for thiacloprid) are possible leachers in the soils and have potentials to permeate into and through groundwater zones.

The photodegradation test indicated that these neonicotinoids are quick to degrade in water and on surface layers of soils under the radiation of sunlight. The half-lives of the neonicotinoids in water under sunlight range from 3.5 to 9.1 hours. The half-lives of the neonicotinoids in top layers of soils under sunlight range from 7.5 to 16 hours. Therefore, the neonicotinoids fallen on the soil surface or run into surface water bodies from foliar spray applications will degrade to very low levels in short periods.

The results of the greenhouse test and the four-year long controlled field test of the neonicotinoids implied that, if the neonicotinoids are applied in a farmland through soil drench or seed dressing once every year, the neonicotinoids will transport down the soil layers and accumulate in subsurface to levels that exceed the regulatory ones that are currently adopted or suggested in Europe or North American countries. If one year sabbatical is allowed for the farmland after six years of applications, the concentrations of the neonicotinoids in the soils will decrease to below the regulatory levels.

The project involved two postdoctoral researchers, nine graduate students, and twelve undergraduate students who participated in the research activities. The students had hands-on experiences in laboratory and field experiments and gained research skills necessary for advanced research engagements in environmental health and safety.


Last Modified: 11/25/2024
Modified by: Yadong Li

The environmental fate and transport of the seven neonicotinoids (imidacloprid, thiamethoxam, clothianidin, dinotefuran, acetamiprid, thiacloprid, and nitenpyram), a new generation of insecticides that are available on the market, were investigated through laboratory, greenhouse, and field tests. The main goal of the project was to understand the long-term environmental impacts of these insecticides through experiments and modeling with fate and transport models verified with experimental data.


Through laboratory tests on the adsorption and desorption characteristics of the neonicotinoids in typical agricultural soils in the southern United States, the degradation patterns and rates in soils and in waters, and the degradation products were discovered. The adsorption distribution coefficients in soils were found to be between 0.96 and 4.2 L/kg for the seven neonicotinoids in typical soil samples taken from Mississippi, Arkansas and Tennessee.

The Groundwater Ubiquity Score (GUS) derived from the experimental data indicate that six of the seven neonicotinoids (except for thiacloprid) are possible leachers in the soils and have potentials to permeate into and through groundwater zones.

Therefore, the neonicotinoids fallen on the soil surface or run into surface water bodies from foliar spray applications will degrade to very low levels in short periods.


The results of the greenhouse test and the four-year long controlled field test of the neonicotinoids implied that, if the neonicotinoids are applied in a farmland through soil drench or seed dressing once every year, the neonicotinoids will transport down the soil layers and accumulate in subsurface to levels that exceed the regulatory ones that are currently adopted or suggested in Europe or North American countries. If one year sabbatical is allowed for the farmland after six years of applications, the concentrations of the neonicotinoids in the soils will decrease to below the regulatory levels.


The project involved two postdoctoral researchers, nine graduate students, and twelve undergraduate students who participated in the research activities. The students had hands-on experiences in laboratory and field experiments and gained research skills necessary for advanced research engagements in environmental health and safety.
